146211446.review:
Great original concept physics based platformer with fun and challenging gameplay, non-linear levels that you can find your own path through, and a quirky yet entertaining storyline. It's basically a rock climbing sim in bread form.

I Am Bread does feel like a bit of an experiment in many ways however and this may disappoint people coming from the superior I Am Fish, which had a full-on, full-length campaign. I Am Bread by contrast only had 8 levels which can be beaten in around 3 hours (though the length is all difficulty so it primarily depends on how good you are), and a lot of secondary content like sandbox mode, bagel racing, etc...

It's still worth the price of admission. If you, like me, enjoy physics based platformers like Trials or Marble Blast and are looking for something different, pick up I Am Bread and throw yourself into an oven today.

144831398.review:
"I Am Bread" is a game that truly takes the phrase "slice of life" to a whole new level, and by slice, I mean you're literally a slice of bread on an epic adventure to become toast.

From the moment I assumed the role of a sentient slice of bread, I knew I was in for a hilariously unique experience. The premise alone is comedy gold. Who would have thought that navigating a kitchen as a single slice of bread could be so side-splittingly funny?

The controls in "I Am Bread" are, well, let's just say they're as wonky as a slice of bread trying to move on its own. Each corner of the bread is mapped to a different key, which means you'll be flopping, flipping, and flinging yourself across the kitchen like a bread ninja on a gluten-filled mission. It's both frustrating and absurdly funny at the same time.

The levels are a playground of chaos waiting to happen. You'll find yourself climbing precarious stacks of dishes, riding a skateboard, and even hitching a ride on a Roomba. The sheer absurdity of these scenarios had me laughing out loud as I watched my bread slice heroically flop its way to toasting glory.

Speaking of toasting, the ultimate goal of the game is to get yourself toasted to perfection. This means navigating the perilous journey through various obstacles and hazards in the kitchen to reach the ultimate prize - the toaster. It's a quest that's both ridiculous and oddly satisfying.

The game doesn't take itself seriously for a moment, and that's what makes it so entertaining. The idea of a slice of bread embarking on a heroic adventure is just too absurd not to love. It's a game that revels in its own silliness and invites players to do the same.

In conclusion, "I Am Bread" is a game that's as lighthearted as it is ludicrous. It takes a simple concept and turns it into a comedy masterpiece. If you're looking for a game that will have you laughing until you're in tears, and if you've ever wondered what it's like to be a slice of bread on a quest for toasty greatness, then this game is the loaf of entertainment you've been waiting for.

143767594.review:
[h1] I Am Bread: A Hilarious Slice of Chaos [/h1]

This game is all about being a slice of bread on a wild quest for toasty glory. Get ready for a rollercoaster of emotions, frustration, and maybe a newfound appreciation for your morning toast.

So, picture this: You are a slice of bread, and your one true goal in life is to become a perfectly toasted piece of golden deliciousness. But, hold your butter, it's not as easy as it sounds. 

Nope, you'll be navigating kitchens, living rooms, and god-knows-where else in your quest to get toasted. And by "navigating," I mean flinging yourself around like a bread ninja.

First things first, let's talk controls. They're intentionally wonky, like trying to steer a piece of bread with a mind of its own. Each corner of the bread corresponds to a different control, and believe me, you'll be laughing and groaning as you flip, flop, and flop some more. It's like trying to control a possessed piece of carb-loaded chaos. But hey, that's the fun of it – the struggle is real, and it's hilarious.

The game's environments are anything but boring. You'll find yourself flopping around the kitchen, launching off toasters, teetering on edges, and causing chaos that only a rebellious slice of bread can manage. Each level presents a unique challenge, and you'll often wonder how bread ended up in some of these places in the first place.

Now, let's talk about gameplay mechanics. You've got a "edibility" meter that's your lifeline, and let me tell you, it's as fragile as a croissant dipped in tea. Every little speck of dirt, jam, or other unmentionable substances will chip away at your edibility. It's simultaneously hilarious and anxiety-inducing, and if that wasnt enough you get graded at the end of each run.

And let's not forget about the rage-inducing physics that'll make you question the very laws of bread nature. Just when you think you've got a grip on things, you'll find yourself glued to walls, flipping uncontrollably, and sometimes just lying there, defeated and wondering where it all went wrong.

But amidst the chaos, "I Am Bread" has a surprising charm. You'll laugh at the absurdity of it all, share your struggles with friends, and maybe even start personifying your piece of bread –and  yes, I've been guilty of that. (I named him "Steven".) 

The game's goofy antics make it strangely endearing, even when you're ready to launch your controller across the room.

Now, it's worth mentioning that "I Am Bread" won't be everyone's cup of tea – or in this case, slice of bread. The wonky controls, the sometimes infuriating physics, and the sheer absurdity of it all might not be everyone's idea of a good time. But if you're in the mood for a game that defies convention, that makes you laugh at its own ridiculousness, and that challenges you to toast yourself against all odds, well, this is it.

In the end, "I Am Bread" is a hilarious, frustrating, and strangely addictive experience. It's a game that doesn't take itself seriously and invites you to join in on the laughter. So, whether you're ready to conquer the bread world or just want to see how your morning toast feels, give it a shot. Just remember – life as a slice of bread isn't as easy as it sounds.

141914191.review:
I bought this game in 2015 after seeing a youtuber play it. I remembered it recently when I saw it in my steam library... apparently I hadn't played very much, so I decided to finish the game. I can see why I didn't play much of it. The quirky funny bad controls get pretty stale pretty quick, and a lot of the game feels unfinished/broken (Even the game's title screen was never changed to say this game is out of early access). I wanted to explore and interact with the levels more, but the design is hostile towards that kind of thinking, putting traps and danger everywhere and not making much of the environment useful other than the stuff that toasts you. I kept interacting with stuff, expecting to be able to turn a radio on, or putting stuff on my bread in hopes of increasing its health or something, but it never worked. The camera also just, sucks a lot of the time.
 
I guess, some positives for the game. The concept is funny. The premise of this eldritch horror bread coming to life and doing everything it can to toast itself for no discernible reason, terrorizing some guy's life in the process, is fun. There's also an easy mode (magic marmalade) which actually solves a lot of the problems I had with the game, allowing for more exploration and creative movement. It does feel weird to have half the mechanics turned off and come out of it with a more fun game. There's some neat extra game modes. These aren't really enough to save the game for me, I enjoyed maybe 20% of it and a lot of the remaining 80% was kind of a slog. It just feels like it was never really finished or refined into something more enjoyable. Still feels like an early access game made for youtube even after all these years.

I cannot quit the game without it crashing. Can't even just ctrl-alt-del and close it, I have to log out of windows and force shutdown EVERY time I quit.

I'm all for a hard challenge in games, but not when it's achieved by fighting the camera and not just the deliberately obtuse controls.

136930733.review:
"I Am Bread" is a unique and quirky indie game that puts players in the role of a slice of bread on an epic journey to become toast. Developed by Bossa Studios, this unconventional game offers a fresh take on the physics-based puzzle genre that will leave players both amused and challenged.

The first thing that sets "I Am Bread" apart is its concept. Playing as a sentient slice of bread may sound bizarre, but it's surprisingly entertaining. The game takes place in various everyday locations, such as a kitchen, a bathroom, or a park, where players must navigate the environment as a slippery slice of bread with the goal of reaching a toaster to become toast. The absurdity of the premise adds a sense of humor and charm to the game that is sure to make players smile.

The gameplay in "I Am Bread" is both challenging and unconventional. Players control the bread's movements, using the corners of the bread as "grip points" to cling to surfaces and maneuver through the environment. However, the bread's limited grip and the physics-based mechanics make controlling the bread a delightful, yet frustrating challenge. Players must strategize and plan their movements carefully to avoid hazards, such as dirt, water, and various obstacles, that can spoil the bread or cause it to lose "edibility points." The game encourages experimentation and creativity, as players can find different routes and strategies to become toast.

The graphics in "I Am Bread" are simple yet effective. The game features realistic 3D environments with detailed textures that make the world feel immersive and believable. The animations of the bread's movements are comical and add to the overall humor of the game. The sound design is also noteworthy, with realistic sound effects that enhance the gameplay experience, from the crunching of the bread's crust to the quirky music that accompanies the bread's adventures.

While "I Am Bread" is a fun and quirky game, it does have some downsides. The controls can be challenging to master, and the difficulty of the levels can sometimes feel frustrating, leading to repeated attempts to complete a level. Additionally, the repetitive nature of the gameplay may not appeal to everyone, as it mainly revolves around navigating the environment and avoiding hazards.

In conclusion, "I Am Bread" is a unique and entertaining indie game that offers a fresh and humorous take on the physics-based puzzle genre. Despite its challenging controls and sometimes frustrating difficulty, the game's quirky concept, creative gameplay, and immersive graphics make it a loaf of fun for players who are looking for a lighthearted and unconventional gaming experience.

136776055.review:
FOV Report: Very poor & non existent

Very narrow FOV with no settings, config, or mods to change it. It is a 3rd person game, but you'll need to be looking around your environment a lot, and I found the narrow FOV to make that kind of headache inducing.

I'm on a field of view crusade. We live in a world where raytracing is common, but a basic quality of life field of view slider is not. There is no excuse other than lazy developers to not include one. If you agree, and want to see more accessible, comfortable gaming for everyone, join me on my crusade and start encouraging devs everywhere to include FOV support.

I cannot in good conscience recommend this game. Both native graphics and DirectX 9 fail to launch. OpenGL, which worked, caused text to appear malformed. I Am Bread seems to be a game of QWOP for baked goods, but it blows my mind how you can be exactly on the toaster yet unable to go in, with no piece of the toast appearing to go slightly in.

Cool concept and great streamer bait, but unless you plan on never beating the first level on a 30-series video card, take your money elsewhere and play a game where the developers don't jump ship.

123746333.review:
Basically a meme game but you can see that some effort has gone into making it feel like a more well rounded experience rather than resting on the laurels of "lol you control a slice of bread, this game is so random".

The main mode is basically to control a slice of bread and guide it to toasting itself. Sounds simple but it is really difficult as you have to avoid getting the bread too dirty and the control are made to be intentionally challenging. Luckily if you're crap at it like me you can get an optional powerup after a couple of failed attempts which makes your slice of bread invincible. I thought that was a nice touch as it at least allows you to explore the levels and experiment without the stress of failing.

There are also a few other game modes to try outside the main one such as a destruction level where you control a baguette and try to cause as much damage as you can within a time limit. Another mode is a time trial where you roll a bagel around through some checkpoints in as fast a time as you can. There's also a few bonus crossover levels with Team Fortress and Goat Simulator.

So all in all you can see that an attempt was made to try and add a bit more fun and variety to this game. But that said, unless you are a masochist and want to try and get the highest ratings in all levels, you'll realistically only get a few hours of enjoyment out of this game.

While it does what it does quite well it's not a game that would be for everyone. If you're looking at this game and thinking it seems stupid, then playing it is unlikely to change your mind. However if you just want a few hours of silly fun then it should do the job.

113666794.review:
I added this game to my library a long time ago during the peak of its popularity on YouTube and played it with some friends for a few hours before promptly moving on to other games. Although I remembered having some fun with this game, I recently decided to try it again to see how this game holds up now, and unfortunately, I didn't have a great time.

This game has a number of different game modes, most of which run through the same set of 7 levels with different goals and gimmicks:
[list]
[*] [i]Story Mode[/i]: This is the main game mode which includes the story, and is definitely by far the best game mode. You control a slice of bread on a journey to become toast, all while avoiding dirt and garbage so you don't become inedible. The story is funny and the different levels are interesting, with lots to explore and interact with. Although the controls are quite challenging to learn and definitely leave a lot to be desired, it's still fun to try and climb through the environments in search of heat sources to become toast. The controls can definitely be frustrating to use though, since the direction don't seem to align with the directions you're looking, and are relative to...something else (I could never figure out what), so you tend to spend lots of time flailing, hoping to go in the right direction. I still had fun with this mode though, so I think it's still worth playing.
[*] [i]Bagel Race[/i]: In this mode, you control a bagel instead, and try to race through various checkpoints in each level as fast as possible. It's not terrible, but it's nothing special, and it's extremely frustrating when you hit something and lose your speed, or are forced to climb (as some levels seem to require), as it's really hard to regain momentum, and the bagel only has two grips you can use to climb, which makes it far harder to control. I didn't really enjoy this mode very much.
[*] [i]Rampage[/i]: In this mode, you play a baguette and try to smash as much stuff as possible to rack up a high score. It's probably the second-most fun mode, and it's a lot of fun to break the glass dishes, especially when you get a crazy chain reaction going. It's fairly luck-based though whether you'll get a great chain reaction (or whether stuff will start breaking immediately when you start, giving you bonus points for doing literally nothing). It's also really hard to control the baguette as it once again only has two grips to use to move it, which is just far harder to do and the directions often makes little sense. Since this mode also creates a lot of debris, it's really easy to grab debris by accident, and for some reason, this makes the physics behave really weird and makes the bread even harder to control.
[*] [i]Cheese Hunt[/i]: This game mode is awful. You play an extremely fragile piece of crackerbread that must climb through the levels in search of pieces of cheese which you must touch to "collect". Not only is it somewhat tedious to find these pieces of cheese, as they're not extremely easy to see, especially from the starting position, but it's way too easy to break the crackerbread by falling a short distance, having an object hit you too hard, or even just by grabbing the wall in the wrong way while climbing, which forces you to restart and makes this mode extremely tedious and repetitive. I didn't finish a single level in this mode.
[*] [i]Zero G[/i]: This game mode is very similar to the story mode, except there's no gravity and you must use rockets to guide the bread to the heat source in each level. I didn't like this mode at all either, because the controls are impossible to figure out. Just like in all the other modes, the directions aren't relative to where you're looking, so it's impossible to tell which direction you're going to be propelling yourself, and since there's no gravity, it can take a ton of work to correct minor mistakes when flying.
[*] [i]Free Roam[/i]: This game mode lets you select the type of bread to use and lets you explore each level with no restrictions. It's really only good for practising, getting achievements, or goofing off if you really want to. It's not awful, but it doesn't really offer much extra.
[*] [i]Ram-page[/i]: This mode is essentially the same as the Rampage mode, except you play as a goat instead of a baguette. I actually found the goat easier to control, because it gives you back four grips like the main game mode, although it's still frustrating, especially since the legs tend to flail around, so it's hard to tell where they'll end up and you often end up waiting for them to hit the ground to continue moving. I honestly prefer this mode to the regular Rampage, but it's controls still leave a lot to be desired.
[*] [i]Team Fortress 2[/i]: This mode is essentially a Team Fortress 2-themed level that is almost identical to the main Story Mode. Just an extra level to play. I probably would have enjoyed it more if I'd actually played TF2 before.
[*] [i]Starch Wars[/i]: This mode is actually a decent Star Wars-themed level where you must attack a Starch Destroyer as a flying piece of bread. The parody is pretty neat and is fairly well done. The controls are entirely different than anything else in the game and it's actually pretty fun. Unfortunately, it's both extremely short and has a complete lack of direction, as it doesn't really tell you what to do, so I ended up wasting a bunch of time before I just looked up how you're supposed to win. It's too bad, because it's pretty fun, and a little bit of direction or guidance would have helped a ton.
[/list]

So after all the game modes, the only ones I really recommend are the main Story Mode and the Team Fortress 2 and Starch Wars bonus levels. This is a very small part of the content in this game, and it probably won't take more than a few hours to play through, so given the lack of good content and the horrendous controls for the price of this game, it just isn't worth it.

I should also mention that the game is fairly buggy and unpolished. The majority of the bugs are physics related issues, such as objects moving or breaking immediately when the level starts, crazy collisions where objects go flying away at high speeds, or issues where you get rocketed away from something you're holding onto in a seemingly illogical direction, often causing you to lose the level. The camera can also be extremely wonky, often moving in weird directions, moving way too close to the bread you're controlling, or clipping through objects. I didn't really have any performance issues like some other reviews have mentioned recently, although I had a couple of crashes as well.

[b]TL;DR[/b] This is a silly game where you control a type of bread and attempt to complete some sort of strange goal, such as becoming toast. It can be entertaining and has a funny story and some interesting environments, but the controls are abysmal, many of the game modes are not good, and there's quite a few bugs with the physics which can be pretty frustrating. Given the lack of content in this game that I'd consider good, I just can't recommend it unless you can get it on a good sale.

I remember this game being fun and today realized it's only 77% positively rated.
After checking the reviews I realized that the negative reviewers just need to get good or stop buying games just because "lol random game" and rather buy games they have a decent reason to believe that they'll actually like.

Also if you play 175.6 hours of this game like Moviebuff83 and have the audacity to say you didn't enjoy the game then it's probably because you [i]made[/i] it unenjoyable for yourself by playing it to death. It's not the game's fault that a fun game turned into a mind numbing slog of obsessive completionism. You did that to yourself. If I had to eat pizza every day for 175 meals straight I'd hate it too.

This game is hard, the controls are torture, and the premise is absurd. If you enjoy Getting Over It then consider this a 3D equivalent without Bennet Foddy explaining the concepts of delayed gratification and perseverance to you. No, for this game you need to already have [i]some[/i] grasp of those things. Even still, this game isn't nearly as unforgiving with distinct levels so you're not going to lose [i]all[/i] your progress and even an easy mode option if you keep failing.

Bueno, aquí mi análisis de I Am Bread:

Descripción general: Como buena rebanada de pan tienes un objetivo: Ser lo más apetecible posible. Y eso es lo que tenemos que conseguir...

Puntos positivos del juego:
- Una idea muy original, que juega muy bien con las físicas.
- La perspectiva y el humor que tiene es muy bueno.
- Tienen colaboraciones de otras grandes sagas, como Goat Simulator y el gran Team Fortress 2.
- hay algún tema músical muy bueno jejeje

Puntos negativos del juego:
- Muy dificil de jugar con teclado. Tal y como advierten, se necesita un mando para poder disfrutarlo.
- Se hace corto el modo historia, aunque se compense con otros modos.
- Largas sesiones de juego te pueden dejar los dedos cansados. Hay que estar preparado para eso.

Valoración general:
Gran idea original de la mano de Bossa Studios, como sus otros juegos. Y te hace plantearte la vida desde el punto de vista de una tostada...

102904376.review:
[i]I Am Bread[/i] is, without a doubt, one of those big games that Steam waves around all over the place as if to say, "We're Steam! We're those guys who provide games like [i]Half-Life[/i], [i]Team Fortress 2[/i], [i]Garry's Mod[/i] and [i]I Am Bread[/i]! If you're one of the true elite gamers, then this is one of the games that you've played!" [i]Surgeon Simulator[/i] is another "big Steam game" that I've had interest in and since I wish to play it, I decided that I would play its long-spoiled prequel [i]I Am Bread[/i] first. The results of my playtime with this game were less than satisfactory.

I know that this game is known for having "wonky controls" as one of its main appealing features, but there were so many times where I felt as though the controller wasn't responding to my inputs in a way that seemed fair. I constantly felt as though I was wrestling the controller into submission to get it to do what I wanted it to do. Even then, it didn't always seem to work like it ought to have worked! If you want to get an "A++" grade on every level, then prepare yourself for a lot of punishment and frustration! Even when you finally do master everything that the game can throw at you, you don't get much of a payoff. All you get is an ending in Story Mode that most people already know about.

I think that this game has two great things going for it and that would be the "Magic Marmalade" invincibility pickup in Story Mode and the Rampage Modes, particularly the one with the goat from [i]Goat Simulator[/i]. The "Magic Marmalade" shows up near your starting point in each level in Story Mode after you've failed the level twice. This gives the player a much easier way to beat the level, thereby allowing access to all of the other modes in the game and to progress further in the main story. The Rampage Modes give you a much-needed opportunity to take out your frustrations about the game by smashing the crap out of everything in each story level with either a baguette or a goat (I prefer the goat).

If you are going to get this game, then I suggest that you only do it if you're interested in the lore of [i]Surgeon Simulator[/i] or if you want to bash dishes, glasses and bottles to pieces with a goat. However, if you're the kind of person like me who is obsessed with earning all of the achievements that you can possibly earn in a game, then I give you fair warning that this game will frustrate you to a point where it's not even fun anymore.

90025800.review:
I am gonna start out by saying that when I review games, I generally go in-depth and look at the design on an objective level, and I try to refrain from making criticisms based on emotion. I Am Bread is kind of infamous for being frustrating and I only decided that I would try to beat it after I managed to beat Getting Over It. I have completed 2 levels so far at the time of my review. I think I should also mention that I am playing with a controller.

THE GOOD:
- Frustrating, but not unbeatable
- Has a nice puzzle aspect to it, and there are often (from what I can tell) multiple ways to toast yourself in the level, if you pay attention to whats around you.
- realistically scaled (for a video game about playing as a sentient piece of bread)

THE NEUTRAL(my nitpick category):
- I wouldn't mind it if the grab object mechanic actually allowed you to rotate around it if you also pressed the trigger/bumber of that corner (which it doesnt, it completely overrides the other controls)

THE BAD:
- The camera can be controlled with the right analog stick, but auto adjusts itself (and I mean completely, even changing the rotation) in some areas, which tends to completely throw off the immersion and flow of the game (From an aesthetic perspective I mean)


Comments:
The ridiculous controls are humorous, but also can get quite frustrating (which I personally see as a good thing, for the kind of game this is) I find that (as was the case when I played Getting Over It) trying to find the humor in the bad controls is the way to go with this game. The story behind this game was interesting to, it just goes to show how video games have evolved over the years that the developers felt the need to explain why the bread was moved from the kitchen and into the other rooms of the house. I believe I read somewhere that this game was actually a prequel to another game made by the same developers which I may or may not check out after I finish this as well.

That being said, I am gonna go into a bit more detail on my only real criticism with this game. Ridiculous controls are one thing, that is kind of the point of this game is to be extremely ridiculous. However when you have a mechanic where the camera can be controlled, having it auto adjust/reset itself is probably the worst (and I don't mean in terms of frustration, but in terms of aesthetic design) thing to implement with that. It wouldn't be that bad if it simply zoomed in/out to accommodate for whats around, because then at least it isn't entirely interrupting the flow of the game, but it also resets the rotation in that case here as well, which completely interrupts the flow of the game, and has actually been what messed me up a few times, not to mention the fact that clashing game-play mechanics tends to ruin immersion in video games. Difficult controls are one thing, but controls that compete with each-other is something else entirely.

Other than the camera, this game can be enjoyable! I give it a 7/10!

Silly, intentionally-horrible controls game that I decided to give a try for the lolz. It started off goofy and silly with a lot of laughs but ended with salt and rage.

These kinds of games weirdly appeal to me but if you have intentionally garbage controls then the rest of the game needs to be solid. Unfortunately, I Am Bread fails at that. The first few levels are good and I didn't run into any bad problems but once you get to the garage the clipping becomes becomes egregious (ie, being able to grab the air and not actually being able to grab a solid object.)

I only tried the main story mode so far. I may try the others sometime in the future if people want to see more of it.

77745769.review:
This is essentially the Water Level of video games.

I am Bread is so embarrassingly un-fun to play that I think it somehow debited some of the fun I got out of the games I played before it. Apart from the general intended frustration of a poorly controlled slice of bread, what is perhaps even more frustrating is the fact that, had the game shipped with properly designed levels that gradually scale up in challenge, it would have actually been enjoyable! It is the sheer staggering degree of missed potential on display here that truly makes this game bad in my eyes.

The premise of this game is hilarious and promising, but the execution is so fantastically terrible that I refuse to believe it was not on purpose. I do not wish to believe that game developers would spend time, money and talent intentionally ruining their own game - and yet, here we are. That's the truly confounding thing here: the game is not frustrating because it's buggy, shoddy or poorly made. You can tell just by playing it for a short time that plenty of care and polish was put in. It's just... they wanted you to NOT have fun playing it.

I can not in good conscience recommend anybody spend any money on this mess. If you can get it for free, it's worth a try, if only for sheer shock value. But only just barely.

73437231.review:
Your crush has asked you out, you have achieved your dream job whatever that may be and live in the home and country of your choice. You can hear the pleasant trickle of a water feature nearby and the sun is shining upon you glittering in the delves of the water feature. You feel content. You feel happy.

At some point you will awake from your daydream of what your life might've become and look back at the screen as you are hauling yourself across a floor in a poorly lit room. A piece of bread covered in ants, dust, droppings of some animal, mustard, jam, a bowling trophy, pieces of glass and battery acid that cannot move except through excruciating difficulty is what you are. You would be forgiven for dismissing life as a grotesque pantomime of which you are the foil.

But you know you are also covered in magic marmalade. The imagination of a man without morals sobbing as he eats toast likely to kill him but nonetheless continues due to the marmalade spurs you on.

Genuinely a very good, well rounded and entertaining game with plenty of gametime and replayability.

You're a slice of bread. You don't have feet, arms, or hands to move around with. The only real method of travelling is making use of the bread slice's ability to stick to surfaces.

And through all the kinetic challenges, you still have to keep in mind that you are, in fact, a piece of bread. A meter of edibility stays at the top of the page, taunting you and reminding you that you have a level of purity to uphold.

Oh, did I mention you have to try and toast both sides at 100%? Good luck with that one!

62479087.review:
The base game mode is the only thing you're allowed to play at first, besides goat mode, so I'll be focusing on that for my review.

So while you may think it's a Goat Sim sort of game, you're not really correct. In reality, it plays more like the lovechild of Octodad and QWOP, in my experience, most comparable to the former. But Octodad has some clear advantages over it, in terms of controls, which is where I Am Bread suffers most imo. 

Bread lacks flexibility, range, momentum, and precision, all of which tie into each other. While at surface level, the same "hold down key to stick, release to move" principle applies to both, Octodad pivots around quite nicely thanks to flexibility, allowing you practically 360 degrees to reach around, with very little hindrance, even from obstacles, making precise motions a matter of simply getting used to the odd controls. Bread, on the other hand, is surprisingly inflexible for not being toasted yet. You try to turn and can only get less than 180, even less so with obstacles and with gravity on vertical sections. Flipping over to change direction can be quite a task if pivoting isn't an option, as you sorta get stuck on yourself, and end up pivoting in some unhelpful direction as you try to flip, rendering the spherical range of motion rather pointless. This also plays into the precision issue, as catching on your own stale self makes precise grabs a nuisance. Octodad, meanwhile, uses separate controls to perform vertical movements, allowing precise grabs with little issue. Octodad has a very wide range of grabbing, whether it's right in front of him or well past his standing height. Bread, meanwhile, is essentially limited to three semicircles centered around whatever corner you're latched onto, and even then, due to your stiffness, actually grabbing the thing doesn't always work like it should. The stretchiness of Octodad also allows him to build up momentum, whether it's sloppily yet effectively running by alternating left and right mouse or outright slingshotting yourself across a hallway, getting from point A to point B may take practice, but is rewarding to master. The convoluted use of all four corners coupled with inflexibility, as well as lack of oomph behind your motions in general, makes building up momentum that you especially need for all the vertical climbs a chore, if not nigh impossible.

I'm not saying I Am Bread has to BE Octodad, but the control schemes are practically identical save for the extra grabs on the former, and of the two Octodad's is just almost entirely better on an objective level, even if some might subjectively prefer the more convoluted and limited QWOP-ish nature of I Am Bread's. 

If you want something that's quirky, yet rewarding to learn, I'd say go with Octodad: Dadliest Catch, because the two games are very similar anyway.

57831706.review:
Dont buy games from Bossa. They are scammers and shut down Worlds Adrift (an only online game) without refund and they knew it was going to happen from day 1.

What you need to know is that Bossa started with a 10 MILLION DOLLAR investment from two companies; Atomico and London Venture Partners. Don't believe me? Read about it in Forbes ( https://www.forbes.com/sites/kittyknowles/2018/05/16/worlds-adrift-improbable-pc-games-gaming-bossa-studios/#31d34bd135b4 ) This money is separate from that which came from "founders," regular players, and funds from the other games created by Bossa. Don't fall for the moronic shills saying this company ran out of money - they never intended to finish it in the first place, it was a pyramid scheme to start with, due to the interest in SpatialOS, which Worlds Adrift runs on.

I hate that I bought this game before this information came to light and I will never buy another Bossa product.

i downloaded this game after remembering how funny it looked in youtube videos back in like 2016. when i first tried to play the game it wouldn't launch. i tried all the options in the launch menu and eventually came across one which allowed the game to launch but i was then sad to learn that despite the game now running it was impossible to play because the text was appearing as a collage of squares and rectangles stuck together. I then went to google to see if anyone else had similar issues to mine ,and apparently this is a common thing, i came across a user claiming that running the game by finding its .exe file had worked for him, when I tried this method the game launched and i happily played the first level-its a rather fun game when it works. Less than a day later i came back to the play the game and it wouldn't launch, so i tried to launch the game using the .exe file as i had before and it had worked, unfortunately using .exe only worked the first time. 

In conclusion- don't buy the game if your wanting to play it.

Positives: i am pleased i only had about 45 mins of play time so i was able to claim a refund and i am glad that the game reminded me to update my 

Negatives: it is literally unplayable....

50842082.review:
After getting killed repeatedly I noticed a fancy invincibility pickup on the table.  Presumably this was to help newbies learn how the controls work.  Well, it did a fantastic job of showing me that either the controls are insanely buggy or my controller - which has been working just fine with every other game I've tried it on - is incapable of managing the number of buttons this game seems to require at once.

So here I am with infinite edibility and grip.  Yet somehow, as I work my way up the side of a counter, I lose my grip.  Repeatedly.  This happened over a dozen times before I got frustrated and quit.  Didn't matter if I was holding on with LB and RB, pushing up and then holding LT and RT, or if I was trying to swing around with one corner at a time - I'd have the new grip confirmed, release the old, and suddenly I'm falling.  Either my controller took the release of, say, RT to mean that I was no longer holding LB as well, or the game went "Ah ha, you didn't really have a grip even though we changed the button color to indicate you did!"

I'm okay with difficult games.  But games that arbitrarily throw you down for no apparent reason aren't difficult, they're just unfair.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED 
So, This is a definitely an interesting game,  Puzzle - 3D - Not 2D/Platform like. 
You think you know puzzle games, this one takes it to a new extreme, 
Definitely not something you can get used to on a first playthrough
Tested on Keyboard and Mouse, as well as controller.

NOTE: 
Notice: You knead a controller to get a real rise out of the game.
LOL: You should also complete the tutorial to get used to Kneading about - As a noob it took me 4:22

#IamBread #BecomeToast #TravelAsBread 

Travel as a piece of bread. Treat your surroundings gently, or they will form part of you. 

6 game modes,  and I think this game deserves its own little channel for all of it. 

You need to perform Key Combos all the time, as the bread needs to move those specific corners to keep going., 

Obviously I did spend the whole beginning as a noob, trying to figure it out, and eventually did the Tutorial to see how it goes. 

Speedruns - Timed runs -  Will be achievable with this game. It's magnificent, and physics based, and your goal is to get to the heat source and cook yourself.

Find the game play here:

45303507.review: I Am Bread is one of those games that you get really frustrated with, but come back an hour later to play. The controls are horrendous and hard to figure out, but simple as well. The graphics are decent, but the real seller of the game is the replayability and uniqueness. Throughout the game, there's a real balance between baby mode, and near impossible throughout the levels, with multiple ways to complete each level too. The best thing about the game is how there's no right way to approach a level, with anywhere bewteen 3 and 40 different ways to complete each one. Not to mention the unique concept as well. It's hard to pick up and hard to master, but it's got such a simple and nice flow in the game, it brings you back, even if you spent 10 hours on the first level. It's a neat game, and one of my favorites. Recommended.

Tags: Simulator - Clumsy/Humor
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: This is object routing with clumsy on purpose controls. Cramp inducing even with Xbox360 pad. Environments are nice but tiny. Core gameplay is poor. Frustrating.

This is a simple game in which you accomplish simple tasks with an inept user interface, with, hopefully, hilarious results. I advise you play Goat Simulator for a more unpredictable goofy experience that actually lets you do things.

If you are into the clumy aspect then I would still recommend Surgeon Simulator over this due to its similarity to the board game Operations and the cringe inducing concept.

I am bread in comparison tries to have an out there, odd presentation. But what it boils down to is a boring, poorly executed puzzle platformer in which you constantly fall into a near insta death pit. (The floor is a death timer but good luck getting off the floor once you get there anyways)

Even Incredipede had the decency to offer small environments and a maneuvrable protagonist. Maybe there is a sweet spot in how you can bounce the slice of bread around and using anchor points but I could not find that feng shui and was left with a very poor impression.

Removing permanently for declutter.

42805706.review:
[url=https://kinglink-reviews.com/2018/06/17/i-am-bread-review/] Full Review [/url] --  [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31803828-Kinglink-Reviews/] Curator Site [/url]

Video Review: 
https://youtu.be/z6VZnvaJ6T8

“Let’s play something completely different.” Oh, those words. I say them entirely too often, but it’s also one of the reasons I think I have an interesting list of reviews. I don’t know why, but I try to avoid only playing AAA titles, and looking at my list I’ve done a fantastic job. But I like to switch between an “AAA” title and an indie title. Well, I don’t think they get much more indie than I Am Bread.

So in 2013, a unique game came out called Surgeon Simulator by Bossa Studios. It tasked the player to do surgery on a patient with just awful controls. I don’t mean that as an insult to the game as they are intentionally bad, but the fact is you had to manually control every finger of a hand to grab tools to work on the surgery. The controls really challenged the player to do the surgery. It was odd, it was unique, and It was a smash hit.

So in 2015, Bossa released a follow up to Surgeon Simulator, simply titled “I Am Bread”. A game which could also simply be called a “Bread simulator”, a new entry in the “bad simulation” genre. While it’s not a genre they created, as QWOP might be one of the original games with intentionally bad controls, it is a genre which they seemed to have shown a mastery with Surgeon Simulator. However, a “Bread simulator”? Hmm how odd, but intriguing. How can one be bread?

The fact is you don’t play “bread” necessarily but rather a seemingly sentient piece of bread that wishes to be toasted. Yeah, I don’t get it either, but I’ve played games where I’m a magical goat wizard so I’ll go along with it.

The story of the game is sparse. Between levels, there are notes taken down by a psychiatrist about a man who thinks a piece of toast has come alive and is wrecking his house. Well obviously he’s right, but the notes don’t really refer to your actions but generic information about what was in the room you were in. Even if you’re very careful and disrupt nothing, the note says you made a mess. Really, that’s the entire story for the game. The game doesn’t tie heavily to those notes, though there is an epilogue level specifically tied to that story. The story is there to avoid people saying “They want a story.” but ultimately I don’t know if the story is necessary for this type of game.

So if the story doesn’t feel important, how is that gameplay then?

It definitely has a feeling that it’s in the same genre as the Surgeon Simulator, but it also feels that it’s more similar to “QWOP” where you independently control the legs and thighs of a runner. In I Am Bread, you get the ability to grip with any of four corners of the piece of bread, and from there you can flip the bread using those gripped corners as the axis.

The easiest movement is to use two bumper buttons on a controller for the “top ” of the bread, and the triggers as the “bottom” and just alternate, and this works well. If you’re on a flat surface and are precise with your motion, you can usually use this to flip towards any goal you want in a straight line. There is a challenge when you need to make a turn but only grabbing with one of the edges allows you to flop around based on that single point, and in that too, it works.

The feeling of the movement is quite odd. The controls are good and usually feel like they’re based on camera direction or bread orientation more than anything, but it’s a game you need to feel to understand how it works rather than just watching someone on youtube. It’s very strange and unique.

At the same time, there’s also a pro-control version, which is actually the original style of the game, and that’s… quite a bit more frustrating to say the least. I can’t exactly explain the difference between the two control styles, but the “Basic” is the newer easier control scheme developed after feedback from the audience. It does make the game remarkably more playable but it’s mostly due to the fact the controls work as you expect 100 percent of the time instead of closer to 75 percent of the time. I’m sure there’s a reason that the pro controls feel so strange and there are probably rules for the motion, but I can’t put my finger on it with the ten minutes of playing with it that I did, and had no desire to continue playing with those controls.

Still, even with the basic controls, the controls can be quite frustrating. When you need to move quickly, the controls are limiting. You want to quickly get off a bad surface or away from a danger and the best you can do is flip away, and the speed that you flip at is slower than you imagine. You need to make proper contact with an object to grab it or grip on it. Sometimes that requires flapping around until you make the “Right” contact. I get all the reasons why the controls are like they are because if they weren’t, the game would be remarkably easy to do everything, but at the same time, I have to admit I got more frustrated with them the longer I played.

The game also has a few rules about “Grip”. You can grip for a certain amount of time on any surface. If that time runs out, you slip and fall to the ground. You can land on anything and as long as you aren’t gripping with any point, you’ll gain that grip power back but running out at the wrong time can doom you pretty quickly.

However, with all these rules, I did find some cool moments and motions in the game with those controls. You’re able to fling yourself in the air. When you do it right, it feels amazing. If you fail, you still feel like a boss doing it because it’s a fun motion to do. The same is true when pivoting on one piece up and over an object, that’s a great moment. Falling and grabbing onto any surface with any of the four corners is also an exciting experience. So while the controls can be frustrating they do have moments of coolness.

But I think the game tried to return to the “Wow, that feels odd” feeling that Surgeon Simulator existed in. It tries to also be random to get weird and zany situations for Youtubers to experience and freak out over or make the player have fun, but really the game itself is too normal for that. The controls are wonky and silly because of it, but the game itself seems like a standard platformer in many level design.

Let me give an example with Surgeon Simulator. You have to do surgeries in surgeon simulator, with the first one being to do a heart transplant. Then after you beat all of those surgeries, you have to do the surgery again in a poorly driven ambulance, and on a gurney riding down the halls, and in space. Even the operations are weird, such as an eye or tooth transplant. This all works because everything is over the top or extreme.

I Am Bread, on the other hand, tries to take the sentient bread, which is a pretty outlandish concept, and then normalize it with a very average world. It’s just a game with weak controls rather than a weird and unique experience.

Another example of how games tackle this type of style is how Katamari Damacy handles its world. Often times you start with a normal looking world, but as you play more and more, you get to see outlandish locations to the point where you want to see what the game does next, or what the game might be hiding behind a door or in a secret area.


If you want to read more and see a final score, you can see the full review with pictures and video at https://kinglink-reviews.com/2018/06/17/i-am-bread-review/. You can also check out my Curator page at If you want to hear more from me, you can show me that by following my curator at http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31803828-Kinglink-Reviews/

40910140.review:
[h1] Let’s review : I Am Bread [/h1]

You are a piece of bread, what is your mission? Get Toasted, actually toasted in a toaster. That is all! Cross kitchens, rooms and living rooms, without touching the floor, otherwise your quality goes down, and you might get something stuck to you, and ruin that perfect Toast!

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

+ Interesting concept!
+ Gorgeous built environments for you to traverse, with great difficulty i might add.
+ A curious control method, 4 keyboards keys that control the ability of each point in the slice of bread to stick to the surface it’s attached to. Resulting in a manner of acrobatics never seen on a piece of fermented cereal mix!
+ Bring out your most destructive Bread Nature, and wreck something on your way to the toaster for increased score!
+ Achievements for that extra difficulty and Cards!

 [h1] Cons: [/h1]

- The controls have a big learning curve, demanding a certain agility with the 4 keys!
- Some glitches regarding textures, but nothing game breaking!
[h1] Final Review [/h1]

I am Bread, goes in the same category as Goat Simulator, it’s just some difficult fun, but above all else, it introduces a new and weird concept, which is always good! It isn’t a game for everyone, while some will relish the difficulty as a challenge, others will be bored by it, but for me I had fun with this, giving it a 6.5 out of 10. 

Enjoy Guys and Girls, and if this review helped you in any way please leave me a Thumbs up, i would appreciate it immensely. And please consider joining me on Curate This – A Honest Review at:
http://store.steampowered.com/curator/31479106/

So it seems sometimes some video game devs are tripping really hard and when reality starts melting away and insanity knocks on your minds door.... your get games like this.
The game idea is pretty simple: you control a slice of bread (!) that probably needs an excorcism since its alive and wants to get toasted really bad. You find yourself in several surroundings of a common household that get more and more unsuitable for bread with each level and try to move to any device that is able to heat you up without touching the ground or whatever nastyness there is for too long. Five second rule, your know? To do this, you control the 4 corners of your slice seperately that you can stick to any surface until your stamina (yup, stamina) runs out.
Does this make any sense at all? Nope.
Is it fun? Hell yes.
Is it hard? Fuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuu.......!
10/10 would toast again.

Have you ever wanted to be bread? This game allows just that. You become a lowly slice of bread who's only desire is to become the toast he/she/bread knows he/she/bread can be. Controls are, as you might expect from setient bread, a bit unwieldy, but that's all part of the fun. Use of an xbox controller is encouraged. This game will likely not break 100 hours on you gaming record, but if you ever just want to sit back, turn on a rerun of your favorite TV show, and game 'til your brain becomes a glutinous mush, 'I Am Bread' will help you get there.

10/10 would share with Incarnacion in her quarters while discussing her favorite animal: puppies.

37217836.review:
Moving past the absurdity and frustration inherent in the thing, this amounts to an interesting physics-driven action-puzzler.
It's a translation of the sort of browser games like QWOP that emphasize directness and specificity of control over ease of control (games where slowly building techniques to exploit the alien but purposeful interface is part of the challenge) into a setting with a 3D world and grander scope.
This isn't a long game, but it's an interesting experience if you like experimental stuff. I do, which is why I'm recommending it.
It is, however, a frustrating exercise in trial and error as you learn how to operate an animate slice of bread.
If you can't tolerate a bit of beating your head against a wall, don't play this.

36024051.review:
I do not recommend this game what so ever. The controls alone are so fustraighting, you have no clear picture in your head that you know what you are doing at all times. You spend more time guessing the bumper pads in hopes something will cling. The analog stick to move the bread will sometimes be forward, or backwards depending on how you grip the bread. 

The bread has no flexibility. You spend all this time to become toast, but the bread feels like toast. The bread should bend more in the middle and fold and flex better, but instead is you get this stiff cardboard bread. Trying to go vertically up anything then trying to clear a 90 degree right angle to get on top of a counter/stove, etc, it's impossible, the bread will not fold and you end up fighting to make simple right angles. 

Then you got the worst camera angles I have ever seen. The camera is 100% zoomed into the bread and there is no way to zoom out to get a more clear picture of the room and your path. Not only that the camera will lock in place and get stuck on objects. If you get stuck behind a dresser, the camera will glitch into the dresser and point to the sky making it impossible to see your bread. 

The game is also so glitchy that my bread will get dirty by touching containers will dirty things inside. What happens is the bread clips through things a lot, like containers and so the bread will grab an object inside a container and pull it through the container magically. Sometimes things just float on the bread, like hovering over it but will still be stuck on it some how. 

Some objectives are to make yourself toast, but how you make yourself toast is the most interesting part of the game. I spent about 5 minutes getting to the toaster on the first level, just to spend 20 minutes just trying to get the dumb bread in the toaster. Then I realized there was a burner on the stove that I can easily lay on top of and become toast to beat the level. But what made me quit this horrific game is on the 2nd level the way you have to become toast is by entering a small slit in the heater on the wall to because toast. After 20 times, I gave up. It is impossible to bend the bread into the small areas. 

Another thing that irritates me is that they give you such a small time for gripping with the bread. Most of the time I am fighting the camera angle in order to see what I am doing, then by fiddling with the camera my grip is losing quick so then I feel rushed. I seriously do not recommend this game.

34645500.review:
Never before have I seen a game based almost entirely around HORRENDOUS control be this much fun.

I think the absurdity of the premise of the game just makes this whole thing work. If it were virtually ANYTHING else, I'd say it's a sack of shit.

In the main game, you are a slice of bread trying to become toast. You can grip surfaces to move yourself and climb around, but you can only grab at each of your four corners, and you can't grip for too long so you have to stop and rest sometimes. And BEWARE THE FLOOR!

The buttons you have to hold down keep changing depending on your orientation, and the camera always seems to work against you. Maybe you're moving in a straight line, but the camera decides to orbit you in a 360 pattern. Or maybe you're trying to figure out how to get up a stack of objects, but the camera keeps putting boxes or other stuff between you and the bread. You may as well try to play the game blindfolded.

Almost every surface is loose, too, so it's not uncommon to have something slip out from underneath you and kill your whole run. Mastering the art of the fling is almost impossible because when you only have one point of grip, you never know what the analog stick is going to make you do.

I enjoy the different games within the game, to some degree. The bagel race is about as infuriating as the main game largely because of the uncooperative camera. And the times you have to beat are INSANE! The rampage game is my favorite because I find it to be the easiest (relatively) but you only have two grip points this time so orienting yourself and making yourself go where you want to go is almost impossible (I often wind up going backwards.) I also don't understand the physics because I can break a glass, send shards flying, and then subsequently grab onto a flying shard and get carried halfway across the room! The Zero Gravity levels are excruciating, and I can't even beat one level of the Cheese Hunt because the damn cracker bread breaks too easily.

Despite all this, the game is still fun. And I can't help but laugh at the whole premise, and chuckle every time I see "I'm not eating that" thrust on the screen. This is a game that is hilarious to watch other people try and beat, but I've found that I can laugh at myself, too. But it will make you very angry, to say the least.

34207162.review:
Silly, charming, but really fucking difficult.

I am Bread was a game that was popular amongst the streaming/let's playing community some time ago (as of this writing). I never allowed myself the opportunity to watch a video, so I went into this game cold. I have to admit, that for a game whose depth begins and ends at the title, this little gem was really a fun time.

I think that with 3 hours into I probably won't sink much more into it. The controls on gamepad are difficult as it is, and I was moderately dissapointed that I couldn't fling myself as well as I wanted to. The fidelity in controlling yourself just ins't there, but then again...you are bread. The fact that I can Spider-Man across a kitchen or living room is probably more control a food item, bread or otherwise, should have.

Numerically, this game is a 5/10: a fun time but one that I have a hard time recommeding someone spend money on. I don't remember where I got this game from (a bundle on Steam or perhaps Humbe Bundle), but I'm glad that's how I got my hands on it. This is a good example of something I'd show my dad and make him play through in order to bond with him (my father being someone who uses but would probably admit to not being very comfortable around computers).

Personal opinion is Eh. I got bored of this game pretty quickly.

Pros?
+You are food.

+You can spread butter or jelly on yourself making you more food.

+Learn what it feels like to be toasted

+Skateboarding

+Spaceship?

Cons

-I recommed having a controller for this, the keyboard controls are wonky and difficult to use, it was like playing Twister with my hands.

There comes a time when all gamers find themselves playing a game that absolutely makes no sense but has a shine anyway.

Well "I Am Bread" is definitely one of those games.

I can't count all the little growls and irratated noises I have made only to finally breathe out that sigh of victory, relief, and frustration all in one go.

You take on the role of a sentient slice of bread, whose only happy little goal in life is to become toast. 
Why do we want to become toast so bad? Well that would be hidden meaning in the stories plot which appears as note cards at the beginning of the level. And a surprise ending.

The game also features various other game modes such as "Find the cheese" where you play a saltine cracker searching for cheese slices, or Bagel Racing which is enough said.

I got this game on sale, which is my reccomendation as it's a decent time passer but really nothing more.

I first came upon this game by watching Markiplier play it one time. Having witnessed his unending frustration with it, I should have known what I was getting myself into when I decided to try it.
The first time was fun. The second, less fun. And it keeps going downhill from there.
The controls are absolutley infuriating and the music in the background only gets more annoying the longer you play. It's almost as if it's rubbing in your face that you haven't reached the toaster yet. Another thing that I hate is how the bread bounces off surfaces when rocking back and forth on one side... totally unnecessary and inaccurate to the laws of physics and freaking gravity. Also, just when you think it can't get worse, the camera completely screws you over so that you either have unneeded trouble seeing, or you can't see at all.
Loved the idea of this concept, but the mechanics are absolute crap. I'd like to meet someone who has been successful with this game and have them teach me their ways, because even as someone who is able to adapt very easily to different sets of controls, I had infinite amounts of trouble with this game.
Do not recommend this game- not for the easily-angered... although it would probably be enough to get the most patient of people yelling and screaming.
I hope whoever designed those controls dropped their toast this morning.

28246838.review:
If you are interested in this game, then you are hoping for the simple kind of silliness that comes from making a piece of bread struggle to be toast but nothing so referential or random as dressing it up in armor while a patsy follows you clacking coconuts on your quest to the Holy Grille. That is mostly what you get. It's hard being bread, but you're bread, and that's funny.

There are two main caveats. The camera sucks, and you have no information.

The camera is as clunky as your movement, but not what you paid to experience. I suspect skill with the camera is similarly acquired as the movement but your initial experience will vastly differ from the perfectly framed trailers and quickly adaptive let's players. And when frustrated from the gradually decreasing grip meter giving out the camera becomes the thing to blame. It also nigh breaks the bagel racing mode.

Aside from that, this game desperately needs some sort of Detective Mode that shows you exact areas of dirtiness and heat. One of the games merits is discovery for the player of different heat sources, but these almost always have a switch. Let's take a 90s era CRT tv, if you owned one you won't know if the developers made the top also hot like a real one or if you'll just have to press against the screen. The iron will seem like the most obvious heat source, but can you still use it if it isn't glowing red like activated hot things? Trial and error necessitates repetition, which will quickly sour the humor of it all. 

However if you don't care about scores eventually story levels give you 'Magic Marmalade' which allows you invincibility and unlimited grip. So you'll always be able to see every level.

28041572.review:
I am Bread may strike people as a novelty game, but it has some real meat behind its fluffy appearance. The amazingly weird premise is bolstered by an intriguing control scheme and physics-based gameplay.  Though it has some crusty edges around its soft center, it has more than enough freshness to warrant a recommendation at its whole sale value. 

As an autonomous piece of bread, your main objective is to move from the rest of the stilted loaves to a place in the same room where you can become toasted. Environmental hazards like used band-aids and dirt reduce your edibility, forcing you to find different pathways as you jitter and flip your way around the house with the shoulder buttons and the left analog stick. The variety is surprising, as you'll find multiple ways to flip, toss, and jiggle your bread with the shoulder buttons. 

It might be weirdly unintuitive at first, but with practice, the controls become quite natural. It ultimately becomes a key part of the game from easily becoming a stale novelty. Suffice it to say though, a controller is a must. The keyboard and mouse combo would only wreck your hands. 

The crusty parts eluded to earlier involve a camera that can sometimes work against you. The angle can change quickly, altering the way the controls and forcing you to compensate for it. It happens infrequently, but leaves an irritating impression when it does happen. The environment could also use some life to it, as aside from the multiple ways to become toasted, there isn't much else to do in it. Some challenging trigger events like turning on the TV (which I found disappointingly unresponsive in the second level), or even a combo of related actions could have added much more value. 

Nonetheless, I am Bread provides fresh, delicious scent to an indie landscape overstuffed with me-too first-person shooter and rogue-lite games. Highly recommended for those looking for a new, action-oriented game and recommended still for everyone else.

28027748.review:
I really wanted to like this game.  I really did.
A crazy game, silly quests, not taking itself too seriously... or is it? It's Bread.  A sentient piece of bread with a desire to be toast. 

Unfortunately, the controls and difficulty make this game too much of a pain to be anything useful or enjoyable.

I attempted to complete the first 3 levels.  The challenge seems to be figuring out what to do as much as getting there.
I tried the Starch Wars, which was entertaining for about 10 minutes, then after the 20th attempt (and intro), I decided this game is not balanced, not well considered, and not worth much more of my time.  I'm sure there's some masochist out there who will enjoy this game, but that is unfortunately not me.

Do NOT pay full price for this game.  If you just happen to get it, then it may be worth your time, somewhat, but really you've got plenty of other games on your Steam games list that are worth much more of your effort. Right?

26470413.review:
Like all wacky physics simulator games it's cute to play for a bit but ultimatly more frustrating than it's worth. And not frustrating in the makes-you-want-to-beat-it-more sense, but in the I-don't-understand-why-that-just-happened sense. 

The controls aren't meerly challenging as they are unpredictable. It's often difficult to tell what pressing forward will cause the bread to do; sometimes flopping one way or the other. The degree of motion is also somewhat confusing. Throwing the stick in a direction  can send the bread in a flying leap or have it just limply flop over. This sounds minor, until you factor in rediculous time limits and surfaces that can rapidly drain your health from a momentary touch. 

The physics engine can't behave itself (check the community page, it's like 60% gifs of the physics bugging out). Which again, is cute to see happen, but when you've spent 5 minutes making your way across a level, only to be thrown across the room by a bug, it quickly turns from cute to controller snapping frustrating. 

If you can pick it up for a couple of bucks the wackiness is certainly charming and distracting, but ultimatly the frustrating lack of agency in the game play will probably have you giving up long before you've explored most of the content.

26167923.review:
first off, i must note I am a very impatient fellow.

That being said, I hate all that is this game. This is a trial and error sort of game, the trouble being every trial can last about 15 minutes or longer.  the first hour of the game is spent trying to get used to the controls. Then you blunder along trying not to touch the floor or other various things through each room. Apparently the controls are better with a controller, but after trying it with my steam controller, they were even worse. I am using a keyboard and mouse, and while I got the controls down pretty good finally, some things are just random and uncontrollable. 
When you are not figthing the controls, you are fighting the camera and it is very hard to navigate up a wall with limited grip time while having to adjust the camera as well and trying to squish yourself up between two tight spaces.

It took me like 20 minutes just to fit inside a toaster thanks to flaily bread controls.
Anyway, the gameplay itself is unique and clever, but not very fun. It is just repeating the same thing over again until you figure something out to get you further along in your helpless search for a heat source.

When you miraculously reach a heat source, good luck trying to find the place where it actually would heat you up. I am not sure if there are certain spots only that are hot, or if the game just isn't working correctly. For example, I was climbing all over a space heater, but only one tiny spot on the whole thing heated me up. As you scramble around the heat source trying to get toasted, you will likely fall off and die. Not very fun.

If you are a more patient human being than I and enjoy doing long repetitions of bread flopping over everything, then buy it. I personally find it very boring, slow moving and frustrating because you never feel truly in control. 

The game does give people like me some help though. If you fail twice on a given level, some super butter or something comes and gives you unlimited life and grip. This makes beating the levels much easier, but it makes a boring game even more boring.

One good thing I can say about "I Am Bread" is that there is a rather large amount of content. Too bad the game is too horrible to play through it all. I usually force myself to beat terrible games, but for the second time in memory, I have had enough after 5 levels.

25899898.review:
We were all told not to play with our food.  Now, our food plays... with us.

Straight out, it's clear this is not a game for everyone.  Expecting a silly Bread 'Simulator' Youtube-sensation smash-em-up?  Look elsewhere.  I AM BREAD needs *surprising* amounts of skill and puzzle solving.  Surprising unless you've played Surgeon Simulator, Bossa's previous game, which likewise required you to train your brain to learn what keys WON'T hurl spoons and scalpels all over the theatre.  This'll sound scathing but some reviewers prefer the Bagel Racing because it's a lot more straight forward and not at all punishing.  If you're interested enough to read this, you'll laugh plenty while you play, yet I AM BREAD will make you feel like your mild-mannered alter-ego has been bashed around the head with a baguette.

[h1]Story Mode:[/h1] Yes, story mode about living bread.  The other modes are a very fun distraction but Story Mode hooked me in.  It's a surgeon simulator prequel!  As surreal and daft as that is, it works. You're taken on an adventure and the world really does become all about one thing: You aren't just bread; you must become TOAST.  You play through as a loaf possessed with life, each slice seeking any and all ways to become everyone's favourite morning accompaniment.  Story Mode takes place over the course of a week.  One of the joys is how the mission at hand engages you completely, and before long the escalating impact of your toasty obsession becomes deadly clear.  This loaf will stop at nothing, slowly pushing its owner into a frenzy while the world (or his therapist and security guards, at least) thinks him insane. 

[h1]Controls:[/h1] You have complete control of every corner and every movement of your wholesome slice, and you will have to learn how not just to grip, but how to flip, how to leap, how to swing and hurl things about to get through the levels.  The levels aren't just kitchens and lounges and petrol stations, because there is an increasing requirement to learn what you've tried out in previous levels to get through the next.  This is one thing that makes I AM BREAD much more of a game than I think a lot of players give it credit for.  It takes timing and practice and a lot of patience - with yourself more than anything!! You'll totally flop on some key manoeuvre and curse your aching fingers, but you'll try again and figure it out.  The only difference between limping across a kitchen surface or crawling painfully up the side of a bin, and flipping across car bonnets or leaping across chasms and flipping gracefully over petrol station shelving, is YOU. 

[h1]Levels:[/h1] Over the course of a week, you'll have to find heat sources, of which there are a few even in the same level, while avoiding anything that'll render you inedible.  Later you'll have to be a bit more creative (and destructive?) in your mission to toast yourself.  It requires level exploration until you spot something, it clicks, or you have that "I wonder if..." moment.  The levels are littered with everyday objects and I adored how everything seemed to move right, from bin lids to swinging petrol station signs, to individual piles of books and rolling gas tanks.  Some things break physics conveniently without going anywhere near the stupidity of something like goat simulator - switches move easily at a stroke, bread is surprisingly strong enough to hurl bricks at cars, and lighters will flick just by touching them.  These breaks are convenient and welcome!  If things get too difficult too often, you are offered a way to become edible no matter what you land on, but I recommend avoiding this.  Staying edible is half the game!

[h1]Other Modes:[/h1] Thanks to Bossa's intent on providing banquets rather than just the one offering (surgeon simulator had several modes by the time they were done), the other modes add content to this game each with its own brilliant twist.  Bagel Racing is easy to get to grips with, though I did initially expect to race other bagels and multiplayer bagels would have been fantastic.  Starch Wars is pretty epic in which you'll take on an evil ironing board and its Rye Fighters.  Rampage puts you in control of a very angry baguette intent on smashing everything, swinging itself about like a baseball bat.  Cheese hunt sees you take on a quest for several pieces of cheese in a room as a piece of Rye, but isn't so interesting.  Zero-G is surprisingly addictive and very nicely done.  I haven't completed the Team Fortress mode but its a quirky version of the same thing and looks a lot of fun as you interact with familiar objects and weapons from comatose Heavy Weapons Guy's world.

It's not a long game, over with in a couple of evenings or maybe 4-6 hours (depending on what you do with the other modes).  It's very silly, great to play with mates or family around, it's got a nice dark glint in its eye, it's easy to play and difficult to master, but your patience and determination will be rewarded.  Remember this is a game in a true sense and you'll be ready - YOU [i]WILL[/i] BE TOAST.  I am a fan.  If you've even read this far, just get it on offer and have a great time.

No spoilers intended here but my girlfriend was absorbed in this game's story and right at the end just asked one question: [i]"Why doesn't Mr. Murton just make his bread into toast?  Then everyone would be happy." [/i] 

Why didn't you just, Mr. Murton?

25606163.review:
You play as a piece of bread with a singular goal: stop at nothing to become toast!  But wait, you must also be edible, so no crawling around on the floor as you complete your quest for a toaster.

You can individually control each of the four corners of your slice of bread, and each corner can be used to grab something.  The bread flops around with ragdoll physics as you strategically alternate between corners in order to flip your way to a suitable toaster.  Controlling the bread is unbelievably difficult, and made worse by poor camera movement, but you do get the hang of it after a few hours of severe frustration.  Thankfully, repeatedly failing every level allows you to optionally become invincible and complete the level without worrying about your edibility.

[i]If the toaster is broken how do I become toast?[/i]

Each level has multiple methods that will allow you to become toast. You can turn on the radiator, break the tv, use the iron, light the grill... the list goes on.  There are also several possible paths to reach each, so you can play each level several times.

The game has quite a bit of humor in it.  Story mode allows you to watch as your owner slowly goes insane.  Starch Wars mode allows you to fly around in a spaceship made from a slice of bread in order to save a baguette.  Team Fortress 2 mode requires you to become a Sandvich.  Other modes have you race around as a bagel, break things as a baguette, find cheese as a cracker, etc.  My personal favorite is Zero Gravity where you can soar through the house.

I think the game is worth a shot, despite the incredibly difficult controls.  Just remember, [i]Nobody wants to eat soggy bread.[/i]
