25157955.review:
I do kind of wish there was a "Neutral" option for this review.

This game falls under the category of games such as Goat Simulator that expects you to find it funny on premise alone, and sadly it's one joke that lands for very few and even if it does land for you it's unlikely you'll find it funny for several hours.

So... Why is this a recommendation?

-Unlike Goat Simulator, there isn't a grand total of one joke per level. It's ridiculous how many puns are packed into the game and some of the more subtle ones actually made me chuckle. There are no shortage of bread puns in this game.
-This game succeeds in the same way Surgeon Simulator succeeded- It actually has merit above just being a game with bad controls. Both this and Surgeon Sim are games with actual learning curves and the potential of mastery- Games where you can actually get better and better at them and earn your A++ rank.
-Actually really, really hard. I'm not even joking, this game is pretty tough especially if you want high rankings.
-Surprisingly open levels. Your goal is to become toast, but there are many different ways to do that- Making your way to a toaster is one, but you could also toast yourself inside an oven or on a BBQ. How you get to something that can make you into toast is also completely up to you, as long as it doesn't consist of crawling along dirty surfaces such as the floor- But even then, skilful play can get you across the floor with minimal damage, too.

But there's a lot of things that drag this game down, too, unfortunately.

-Like Surgeon Simulator's A&E Edition it outstays its welcome. The campaign mode is at a pretty good length, but if you want 100% completion in this game it will be an incredibly painful and boring experience. They mix it up with different kinds of bread but it isn't really different enough to work particularly well. Especially with all the extra stuff they've added through updates. It's very unlikely you'll actually have the interest to play every extra level at least once.
-The controls are actually TOO bad. Surgeon Sim is a game that appears to have bad controls to the uninitiated, but all you need to do is actually learn the controls and the controls will no longer be an obstacle to your play. I Am Bread, on the other hand, doesn't appear to have that quality- No matter how good you get the game's physics engine will still screw you over at times because your very movement is dependent on the game's physics engine. This may have been because of the fact I didn't use a controller but I still feel like even movement felt more difficult than it needed to be.
-Once again, it may be because I didn't use a controller, but those zero-gravity levels... UGH.
-There didn't appear to be any secrets or secret levels like there were in Surgeon Simulator. Surgeon Sim had this titanic number of easter eggs and so on that were pieced together in order to discover an amazing secret level- I Am Bread doesn't have anything like that.

Overall I Am Bread is IMO not as good as Surgeon Simulator was. It still manages to do what games of its type consistently fail to do but it's a downgrade to what Surgeon Sim was. It's not exactly a game I can muster up a "Not Recommended" rating for because it does have merit especially if this kind of game is what you're looking for, but I'd still recommend you pick up Surgeon Sim instead of this.

24947445.review:
QWOP with toast.

If you aren't familiar with QWOP, it is a game where you have to control someone's individual joints to make them run/walk. It is incredibly awkward as a control scheme and is basically a joke game.

I Am Bread is basically that, except instead of controlling a person, you control a piece of toast. You can stick one or more of the corners of the bread to a surface in order to move, flipping over and over again to get around the level. You can stick to anything, and ultimately, the game is a bit of a physics puzzle.

The problem is that the incredibly awkward controls are endlessly frustrating. Getting into the toaster in the first level is an arduous, unpleasant task which takes an enormous amount of work. The toast flops around freely and almost uncontrollably, and while it is not that hard to simply move around large, flat surfaces, any sort of specific positioning is an awful, awful chore.

And that's just the first level.

This game is endlessly frustrating and unless you actually, genuinely enjoyed QWOP, this game will drive you batty.

23629397.review:
You've just spent 15 minutes climbing up walls, carefully edging your way around bookshelves, deliberately nudging yet another expensive ornament to the floor far below.  Just across the room - your holy grail, your final destination: a source of heat.  But between you and toasty nirvana, a colossal THREE FOOT gap.  It feels like a mile. You grab onto the bookshelf with one of your corners, and catapult yourself across the gap as hard as a piece of bread possibly can.  With this final leap of faith, time seems to slow down from the exhiliration as you pirouette through the air.  Just as you slam into the opposite surface you desperately cling on with every corner that makes contact like a tiny, wheaten spider-man.  You only have a few moments to hold on, and with sheer panic you begin to flail your way towards the heat source.

Except, it was a lamp, and your impact knocked it over.  You're now vertical, holding on for dear life with one corner, hoping against hope that you can just maintain your grip long enough to finally become toast.  50%.  70%. 90%!  You flip around to toast the other side, feeling your grip begin to weaken.  "NO! I WAS SO CLOSE!" you scream inside, as you feel your victory slipping away, and finally you fall.  You now lay on the floor, in a pile of toenail clippings, inedible and unwanted - nobody likes toejam toast.

You start again, yet another slice from the same loaf.  This time, you anticipate the situation and stay on the side of the lamp, so when it finally lands, you're on top.  The feeling of accomplishment growing inside you as you watch that bread slowly turn golden-brown is unlike anything else in modern gaming. You are a genius! You are a champion! You are TOAST!

23460440.review:
Not a game for everyone, lets just get that out of the way. But I do suspect Dark Souls players, such as myself, are in the right mind-set to understand I Am Bread, and enjoy it. Once I got the right idea, it became addictive and, amazingly, rather meditative.

In terms of gameplay it's slow and takes loads precission and patience. If you're expecting run-and-gun instant satisfaction, look elsewhere, this is not a CoD generation experience. Make your way through a level at a snails pace, enjoying the journey, however, and victory is incredibly rewarding. Yes, the controls take getting used to, but it honestly didn't take as long as I thought to have my bread doing air-flips.

One major issue that can't be ignored; the camera is not your friend. And in a game requiring such concentration and precission, that can be a right pain in the ass. (Likewise with Dark Souls.)

All in all, I tip my hat to the developers for originality, incredible detail, and amazing sound design. (The music gets repetitive quick, but the sound of physical objects is outstadning.)

Due to popular demand Ive decided to add a more ‘wholemeal’ first look review for people who like that sort of thing. 

The game is essential qwop combined with the floor is lava. You navigate your slice of bread around various obstacles on a quest to get yourself nicely toasted (insert your own joke there). Encountering dirty items reduces your edibility and therefore your overall score, whilst getting smothered in tasty tasty jam boosts it.

The game controls exactly how you would imagine it does. Each corner is assigned a different button which when pressed holds that edge in place apparently regardless of the surface/physics. The mouse or thumb stick flicks the bread around of can be used to nudge it around for precise movements. Practiced or naturally skilled will surely be able to cartwheel their way onto the leaderboards quickly whilst people starting out will ultimately spend more time flailing around like a dying Magicarp. Your main opponent is your own frustration.

If the play style is sounding very familiar that’s because it is. Anyone who has already played Surgeon Simulator or Octodad will immediately recognise the pattern of destruction and failure. This means that behind its freshly baked exterior the game is likely to become stale fairly quickly. Like its sister games there is a big potential for fun workshop content but ultimately you cannot judge a game on what could possibly be made by fans later on.

It is worth pointing out that it is an early access game, meaning that it is essentially unfinished, although this game does feel a lot more complete than most. It is very much playable with the exception of a few minor bugs. Enabling the gif record mode makes the game basically unplayable and the music always seems to be coming out of a random corner of the room.

I think overall most people will have already made a decision about this game, and whatever your thoughts they are probably correct. It’s ultimately a casual iPad-destined meme-maker but it clean fun and will give most people a few laughs for less than the price of an average cinema ticket. If flinging a slice of bread around for a few hours is the sort of thing that will brighten your day, then this is probably for you.

22865752.review:
A very, very cute novelty game where the bad controls are fully intentional to make it challenging.

It is fully possible to beat this game with a low-mid skill set, but you won't be getting A-rank on any missions.

Gamepad support is inbuilt, and allows for both Xbox 360 Icons during Gamepad play as well as Ps1/Ps2/Ps3/Ps4 icons (my personal preference, before getting a gaming PC I was a Playstation gamer, and over 10 years of using one has buried the button locations so firmly in my mind that that's my default for gamepad and Xbox style baffles me (even though I have a Xbox gamepad because it is more compatible with PC games than a PS3 one).

Assorted updates have added silly (but fun) new gamemodes/maps such as Starch Wars (where you take down an ironing board star destroyer against bagel-shaped TIE fighters), TF2 (where you get to play as Heavy's Sandvich) and Goat (in collaboration with Goat Simulator, where you get to destroy the I am Bread worlds as a goat).

Also, it's a prequel to Surgeon Simulator.

22112551.review:
Do I recommend this game? Yes and no is the simple answer. The more elaborated answer is a bit more... complicated.

Yes, I recommend it because:

+ The ultimate challenge for your patience
+ wonderful, playful music
+ nice graphics
+ excellent idea

But I don't recommend it because:

- It's way too hard and unforgiving for its own good (imho).
- Short soundtrack - all though lovely, I only played like 70 minutes, and I already got tired of the soundtrack


I want to comment a little bit more elaborated on the "too hard for its own good"-point here. I know this game is supposed to be hard, and I know it is the ultimate challenge. But in my opinion there are too many factors that makes you fail in order for this to be fun to play. Prior to ordering this game, I was just thinking that people were too bad gamers and soar loosers for down-voting this game due to its controls and being too hard. But now I understand them.

It is hard enough to master navigating the bread; but once you learn that it's quite simple. HOWEVER, what I cannot grasp is why the most difficult aspect of this game is to get into the God forsaken toaster??? You've just been through hell to get to the toaster, and then you simply cannot get into the bloody thing. On the first story mission I mastered my skills to get to the toaster in like 3 - 4 minutes, which is quite good considering I just bought the game. But then you are rewarded by having to spend another 5 minutes to get the bread to actually go into the toaster. And that blew a fuse for me.

The second thing that makes this game too difficult is how unforgiving it is; not only do you loose edibility (health), but also have a grip-counter which is way too short/small considering how you are sometimes supposed to hang above the floor infront of a grill in order to become toasted. 

It is also not rewarding enough. The grading scale in the end is way too demanding, which more often than not sends out a vibe that "Hey, You suck ballz!". I mean, I don't expect an A-grading for completing a mission in 10 minutes, but a D when I lost no health at all? That is just mean.

So how to "fix" this game in my opinion? Make it a bit more forgiving; don't make it so difficult to get into the toaster after all the hell getting to the toaster, indicate WHAT is the toaster (it is difficult enough to get to it, you should not have to search for WHAT is the toaster), and make the toast more responsive to your controlls.

All in all: If you like to torture yourself, and/or have an incredible amount of patience, this game is for you. The concept is brilliant. But considering the immense difficulty of the game I would not recommend this for the weak-minded (I guess I am a weak-minded gamer in this sense). 

My final verdict is a 7/10 for being a brilliant concept with good graphics and being a game that really stays true to its intended gameplay. But NO, I don't recommend this, unless you have some serious nerves of steel and is serious about sitting hours just to get through one or two levels of the game.

21934076.review:
I am Bread is a third Steam game by Bossa Studios who are known thanks to their crazy Surgeon Simulator. If you've already seen (or played) the game, you know it challenges players by having difficult controls that makes it frustrating but also hilarious to play. In this case, they did it in pretty similar way, with important difference: You will be in control of a slice of bread that wants to get toasted. ([i]A great potential friend for toaster from Red Dwarf![/i])

Yes, it's a weird physics simulation game where you are trying to move bread towards a source of heat. Controls revolves around four buttons - a button for each bread's corner that makes it sticky. If you are now thinking about the movement, you have probably already thought out that all the movement is done by swinging and flinging on those stickied bread corners.

I can't say it would be unexpected after Surgeon Simulator, but it's still important to say that I am Bread is a difficult game. It has a high level of difficulty, you'll be raging a lot because while you'll be trying to get to get toasted (by toaster or table lamp, for example), you'll also have to dodge all dirty and wet areas and objects. Don't even think about touching ground! It's like the floor is lava, it makes you taste bad which leads up to the game over screen. And one more thing, you have limited "sticky timer". You can hold on some place swinging just for a moment, then you have to lay somewhere to regain your energy for being sticky.

While it's definitely a great game for skilled speedrunners, don't expect to get into it easily, you'll need a lot of practice to beat levels without getting dirty. Good thing is that the developers knew how begineers will suck at it, so after two times you lose a level, you'll get an option to remove the sticky timer and edibility meter (edibility is reduced by getting dirty).

The main story mode offers a classic level list with funny short story, delivered via medical reports, about a man who gets crazy because he thinks that a slice of bread is destryoing everything in his house. But there's more! There's also a cheese hunt, bagel race (probably the easiest game mode), rampage (where you have to destroy everything with baguette), zero-g (to make you even more frustrated), and free play mode.

It's worth mentioning that developers made a lot of free content for I am Bread later after release - Team Fortress 2 bread level, Goat Simulator mode (just change bread for goat) and Starch Wars mode, which is a kind of weird 3D space shooter with laser bread (referencing Star Wars, of course). Even if it's been done with the idea of cross brand marketing, I really appreciate that those updates came up for free!

The game supports keyboard and mouse or gamepad controls. While other players had problems with controllers, I played with Xbox 360 controller without any problem, haven't seen any lag through my gameplay sessions.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
I am Bread is a perfect game for those who want something silly but difficult. It requires a lot of practice to get good at it, so depending on your perseverance, it can offer you many hours of entertainment and huge self-satisfaction in the end... or a lot of frustration. So it depends on your temper, but it's definitely worth buying.

21766358.review:
There's challenging gameplay, there's unforgiving difficulty, and there's broken clumsy controls. The challenge in I am Bread doesn't come from the gameplay, or the missions, or the success conditions, but instead from fighting with the controller to do what you want it to do. If the player fails it should be due to his or her actions, not because the game decides to work against their inputs.

The humour of the game wears off quickly and it isn't enough to carry the frustration that comes from the core gameplay. Rampage mode is a nice option and serves as pure catharsis. I would actually be more interested in playing a fully-fleshed out Katamari Damacy style game with the rampage mechanics.

Overall, probably worth a try but I wouldn't pay full sticker price.

This was the first game I ever refunded.

I'd be okay with that if the gameplay was enjoyable, but it isn't. You're a piece of bread and you move around with the agility you'd expect of a piece of bread. 

In many games like this, the bad controls add to the character or humor of the game. In Surgeon Simulator, for example, the failure is largely why the game is so much fun. But this is just bread. The humor doesn't last five minutes. 

I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone.

20336275.review:
BUY/SALE/PASS:  Sale - Wait for a sale price

About ten years ago, there came along a budget title out of Japan named Katamari Damacy.  In the tiny feet of a diminutive prince, players were tasked with picking up whatever random crap was strewn around a room/house/neighborhood/city/planet as fast as you can.  It was strange, yet strangely compelling; an oddity of video games that came out of nowhere and has since been milked dry as a concept; even the original creator has distanced himself from the series.  Weird games slowly drift by the wayside as video games break way into the mainstream, and things become normal.

Then, in 2015, players were tasked with playing as a slice of bread.

Bossa Studios, the creators of Surgeon Simulator 2013, bring us yet another bizarro creation.  As a single slice of bread, your mission in I am Bread is to get toasted by any means necessary.  Gripping the surfaces and objects around you with the corners of your bread slice (somehow…), you must traverse the various rooms of a house to find that sweet embrace of heat that will get you nice and crispy.  But don’t land anywhere gross or linty!  Otherwise you’ll end up inedible, and what will even be the point of being toasted?  The horror of such a thought!

I am Bread is utter nonsense baked into a bizarre, fluffy bun.  Yet the gameplay is so fun and goofy, oftentimes creating some of the best accidentally funniest moments of any game released this year.  Purposefully frustrating controls leave the player pulling out their hair one moment and laughing the next.  There’s no escaping it.  You are bread.  And you will be toast, one way or another.  Delightful music, fun gameplay, funky concept, all worthy of a sale price purchase.

20201954.review:
Overall a decent game worth a try, however the abysmal 3rd person camera, inconsistent visual detail and iffy physics killed most of the enjoyment I felt I would get from this game. 

I played SS previously and that was a pretty fun gem, yet it did have some quirks and an excessive amounts of clipping. Bread, I don't feel, is anywhere near as good as SS. 

Bread's friendship with Goat Simulator sort of reduced my minimal respect for such an original game, that is Bread. GS is an extremely buggy game that thrives off of bugs, glitching and clipping, all are annoyances of mine. Labeling weak coding and QC as an aspect of gameplay doesn't cut it for me. I felt Bread went down that route a little bit, which I don't like. 

Performace of Bread is questionable. I get huge frame rate drops when the Goat destruction levels start up and also every time I break that jar of jam with the bread. Speaking of the jam, the glass containers in this game look like something from a 2005 title. They are a huge eye sore, and they are everywhere. Technology exists today that makes glass look realistic... please use it. This is a 2015 title. Even with it being from a small developer, they still have enough money to get some decent looking glass going on. 21st Century Fox is a partial owner of Bossa, there's tons of money there to get some better graphics and coding. Hopefully they go down this route as Bossa becomes more popular. I hear they're working on a MMO open-world title right now... yikes. That's a huge jump. 

Speaking of graphics, it's hit or miss in each level. The few levels towards the end are the worst, visually. It doesn't make sense why this is even happened other than laziness, or they ran out of time. The game has a gradual decline in graphics the further you progress. I see tons of low res textures, a very poor sky box, background visuals look like they're from the 80's, etc. Graphics aren't everything, but they are important. 

Some visuals are cartoony, some are more heavily detailed.... don't mix this sh**, pick one and go with it for the whole game.

The third person camera... Christ. Yes, many games suffer from third person camera issues, especially those old GTA games, but lets get this sh** cleaned up, guys. It jumps around everywhere, clips through everything, hinders those bagel racing levels like crazy, and is poorly optimized. It pisses me off. Unity can do better. 

Iffy physics. Props and movable objects sometimes do move around in a natural manner when you grab them or push them, but not all of the time. It's inconsistent, like the visuals. I've gotten stuck on props many times, and have had myself, and different objects bounce unnaturally in different directions, before saying to myself "wtf is this sh**, seriously?" 

Negatives aside, Bread does have its moments. I'm glad the 0 gravity mode is back from SS. It is very difficult to control, but is rewarding when you beat it. The humor is nice. The game is fun to watch. The concept is fresh. Like SS, the controls and movements have a steep learning curve, but is awesome when you get it down. 

Like I said previously, maybe give the game a whirl, it's pretty unique. Like SS, it requires a lot of patience. As for the questionable overall quality, Bossa: talk to Fox and get some heavy funds rolling in, hire a few more devs (get some people from big triple-A companies), get some Unity pros to work with ya'll--Unity can accomplish so, so, so much more. 

Thanks.
